episodes.title: 566: Reduce Organizational Drag
episodes.summary: Michael Mankins, Bain & Company partner and head of the firm's Organization practice, explains how organizations unintentionally fail to manage their employees' time and energy. He also lays out what managers can do to reduce what he calls organizational drag. Mankins is a coauthor of "Time, Talent, Energy: Overcome Organizational Drag and Unleash Your Team’s Productive Power."

episodes.title: 565: Globalization: Myth and Reality
episodes.summary: Pankaj Ghemawat, professor at NYU Stern and IESE business schools, debunks common misconceptions about the current state and extent of globalization. (Hint: the world is not nearly as globalized as people think.) He also discusses how popular reactions in Europe and the U.S. against globalization recently could affect the global economy, and how companies will need to adapt to the new reality. Ghemawat is the author of several books on globalization, including “World 3.0” and most recently “The Laws of Globalization and Business Applications.”

episodes.title: 564: Why You Should Buy a Business (and How to Do It)
episodes.summary: Richard S. Ruback and Royce Yudkoff, professors at Harvard Business School, spell out an overlooked career path: buying a business and running it as CEO. Purchasing a small company lets you become your own boss and reap financial rewards without the risks of founding a start-up. Still, there are things you need to know. Ruback and Yudkoff are the authors of the “HBR Guide to Buying a Small Business.”

episodes.title: 563: Escape Your Comfort Zone
episodes.summary: Andy Molinsky, professor of organizational behavior at Brandeis International Business School, discusses practical techniques for getting outside of your comfort zone, and how that can develop new capabilities and experiences that can help your career. His new book is “Reach: A New Strategy to Help You Step Outside your Comfort Zone, Rise to the Challenge and Build Confidence.”

episodes.title: 562: Business Leadership Under President Trump
episodes.summary: Larry Summers, former U.S. treasury secretary, is calling on American business leaders to stand up to President Donald Trump. Summers sharply criticizes the administration’s protectionist agenda, and he says it’s time for executives to call out how those policies undermine the economy and the country's best interests in the long term.

episodes.title: 561: Generosity Burnout
episodes.summary: Senior leaders Brad Feld, Sarah Robb O’Hagan, Mike Ghaffary, Heidi Roizen, and John Rogers Jr. discuss burning out on giving, the techniques they use to avoid it, and how they recognize it in their employees.

episodes.title: 560: Stopping and Starting With Success
episodes.summary: Jerry Seinfeld shares his insights into innovation, self-criticism, and how to know when to quit. The U.S. comedian conquered 1990s television with his sitcom and is now finding a new audience for his online talk show, "Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee."

episodes.title: 559: Voices from the January-February 2017 Issue
episodes.summary: Roger Martin of Rotman School of Management, Paul Zak of Claremont Graduate University, Clayton Christensen of Harvard Business School, comedian Jerry Seinfeld, and HBR Editor-in-Chief Adi Ignatius respectively discuss customer loyalty, the neuroscience of trust, entrepreneurship in Africa, the source of innovation, and the new, hefty magazine. For more, see the January-February 2017 issue.

episodes.title: 558: Collaborating Better Across Silos
episodes.summary: Harvard Law School lecturer Heidi K. Gardner discusses how firms gain a competitive edge when specialists collaborate across functional boundaries. But it’s often difficult, expensive, and messy. The former McKinsey consultant is the author of the new book, “Smart Collaboration: How Professionals and Their Firms Succeed by Breaking Down Silos.”

episodes.title: 557: Restoring Sanity to the Office
episodes.summary: Basecamp CEO Jason Fried says too many people find it difficult to get work done at the workplace. His company enforces quiet offices, fewer meetings, and different collaboration and communication practices. The goal is to give employees bigger blocks of time to be truly productive.

episodes.title: 556: The Secret to Better Problem Solving
episodes.summary: Thomas Wedell-Wedellsborg discusses a nimbler approach to diagnosing problems than existing frameworks: reframing. He’s the author of “Are You Solving the Right Problems?” in the January/February 2017 issue of Harvard Business Review.

episodes.title: 555: What Superconsumers Can Teach You
episodes.summary: Eddie Yoon, author of "Superconsumers" and growth strategy expert at The Cambridge Group, explains how companies can find their most passionate customers and use their invaluable insights to improve products and attract new customers.

episodes.title: 554: The "Jobs to be Done" Theory of Innovation
episodes.summary: Clayton Christensen, professor at Harvard Business School, builds upon the theory of disruptive innovation for which he is well-known. He speaks about his new book examining how successful companies know how to grow.

episodes.title: 553: Handling Stress in the Moment
episodes.summary: HBR contributing editor Amy Gallo discusses the best tactics to recognize, react to, and recover from stressful situations. She's a contributor to the "HBR Guide to Managing Stress at Work."

episodes.title: 552: How Focusing on Content Leads the Media Astray
episodes.summary: Bharat Anand, author of The Content Trap and professor at Harvard Business School, talks about the strategic challenges facing digital businesses, and explains how he and his colleagues wrestled with them when designing HBX, the school's online learning platform.

episodes.title: 551: Why the White Working Class Voted for Trump
episodes.summary: Joan C. Williams, distinguished professor and director of the Center for WorkLife Law at UC Hastings, discusses the white working class voters who helped elect Republican Donald Trump as U.S. President, and why Democrat Hillary Clinton did not connect with them.

episodes.title: 550: A Leadership Historian on the U.S. Presidential Election
episodes.summary: Harvard Business School professor Nancy Koehn talks about the surprising election of businessman Donald Trump as U.S. president, and what leaders throughout history can tell us about bridging divides and leading in times of uncertainty.

episodes.title: 549: Re-Orgs Are Emotional
episodes.summary: Stephen Heidari-Robinson and Suzanne Heywood, authors of "ReOrg: How to Get It Right" explain how good planning and communication can help employees adapt.

episodes.title: 548: The 10 People Who Globalized the World
episodes.summary: Jeffrey Garten of Yale School of Management discusses how Genghis Khan, Mayer Amschel Rothschild, Margaret Thatcher, and others made the world more integrated. Garten is the author of "From Silk to Silicon: The Story of Globalization through Ten Extraordinary Lives".

episodes.title: 547: What the World's Best CEOs Have in Common
episodes.summary: Long-term thinking, short-term savvy, and relentless focus on employees.

episodes.title: 546: Power Corrupts, But It Doesn't Have To
episodes.summary: Authority changes us all. Berkeley's Dacher Keltner, author of the HBR article "Don't Let Power Corrupt You" and the book "The Power Paradox" explains how to avoid succumbing to power's negative effects.

episodes.title: 545: When Not to Trust the Algorithm
episodes.summary: Cathy O'Neil, author of "Weapons of Math Destruction" on how data can lead us astray–from HR to Wall Street.

episodes.title: 544: Macromanagement Is Just as Bad as Micromanagement
episodes.summary: Tanya Menon, associate professor at Fisher College of Management, Ohio State University, explains how to recognize if your management style is too hands off. She's the co-author of "Stop Spending, Start Managing: Strategies to Transform Wasteful Habits."

episodes.title: 543: Building Emotional Agility
episodes.summary: Susan David, author of "Emotional Agility" and psychologist at Harvard Medical School, on learning to unhook from strong feelings.

episodes.title: 542: Excessive Collaboration
episodes.summary: Rob Cross, professor at the University of Virginia’s McIntire School of Commerce, explains how work became an exhausting marathon of group projects. He's the coauthor of the HBR article "Collaborative Overload."

episodes.title: 541: Making the Toughest Calls
episodes.summary: Joseph Badaracco, Harvard Business School professor, explains what to do when no decision feels like a good decision. He is the author of "Managing in the Gray: Five Timeless Questions for Resolving Your Toughest Problems at Work."

episodes.title: 540: Email: Is It Time to Just Ban It?
episodes.summary: David Burkus, author of "Under New Management", explains why some companies are taking extreme measures to limit electronic communication. Burkus is also a professor at Oral Roberts University and host of the podcast Radio Free Leader.

episodes.title: 539: The Connection Between Speed and Charisma
episodes.summary: Bill von Hippel, professor at the University of Queensland, on how the ability to think and respond quickly makes someone seem more charismatic.

episodes.title: 538: How Work Changed Love
episodes.summary: Moira Weigel explains how the changing nature of work has reshaped the way we meet, date, and fall in love. She's the author of "Labor of Love: The Invention of Dating" and is completing a Ph.D. at Yale University.

episodes.title: 537: Negotiating with a Liar
episodes.summary: Leslie John, Harvard Business School professor, explains why you shouldn't waste time trying to detect your counterpart's lies; instead, use tactics drawn from psychology to get them to divulge the truth. She's the author of the HBR article "How to Negotiate with a Liar."

episodes.title: 536: In Praise of Dissenters and Non-Conformists
episodes.summary: Adam Grant, Wharton professor and author of "Originals", on the science of standing out.

episodes.title: 535: The Zappos Holacracy Experiment
episodes.summary: Ethan Bernstein, Harvard Business School professor, and John Bunch, holacracy implementation lead at Zappos, discuss the online retailer's transition to a flat, self-managed organization. They are the coauthors of the HBR article "Beyond the Holacracy Hype."

episodes.title: 534: The Era of Agile Talent
episodes.summary: More of us are working in organizations employing a mix of freelancers, contractors, consultants, and full-timers, explains Jonathan Younger, coauthor with Norm Smallwood of "Agile Talent: How to Source and Manage Outside Experts."

episodes.title: 533: We Can't Work All the Time
episodes.summary: Anne-Marie Slaughter on (finally) bringing sanity to the work/life struggle.

episodes.title: 532: Teaching Creativity to Leaders
episodes.summary: Tim Brown, CEO and president of IDEO, on breakthrough problem-solving.

episodes.title: 531: Brexit and the Leadership Equivalent of Empty Calories
episodes.summary: Mark Blyth of Brown University and Gianpiero Petriglieri of INSEAD discuss Britain's vote to leave the European Union.

episodes.title: 530: A Brief History of 21st Century Economics
episodes.summary: Tim Sullivan, co-author with Ray Fisman of "The Inner Lives of Markets," on how we shape economic theory -- and how it shapes us.

episodes.title: 529: Greg Louganis on How to Achieve Peak Performance
episodes.summary: The champion diver explains how visualization and ambitious goal-setting helped him achieve double gold medals in back-to-back Olympic Games and why he now serves as a mentor to younger athletes and a spokesman for LGBT causes.

episodes.title: 528: Getting Growth Back at Your Company
episodes.summary: Chris Zook of Bain explains the predictable crises of growth and how to overcome them. His new book is "The Founder's Mentality," coauthored with James Allen.

episodes.title: 527: Asking for Advice Makes People Think You're Smarter
episodes.summary: The research shows we shouldn't be afraid to ask for help. Francesca Gino and Alison Wood Brooks, both of Harvard Business School, explain.

episodes.title: 526: Yo-Yo Ma on Successful Creative Collaboration
episodes.summary: The acclaimed cellist explains how he chooses and works with partners and shares advice on honing one's talent.

episodes.title: 525: Be a Work/Life-Friendly Boss
episodes.summary: Managers play a huge role in their employees' personal lives, which in turn affects productivity, morale, and turnover at work. Professor Scott Behson, author of "The Working Dad's Survival Guide," and professor at Fairleigh Dickinson University, gives practical tips for being a leader who is flexible, fair, and effective.

episodes.title: 524: Make Better Decisions
episodes.summary: Therese Huston, Ph.D. and author of "How Women Decide," offers research-based tips for both men and women on how to make high quality, defensible decisions -- and sell them to your team.

episodes.title: 523: Let Employees Be People
episodes.summary: Robert Kegan and Lisa Lahey, both of Harvard, discuss what they've learned from studying radically transparent organizations where people at all levels of the hierarchy get candid feedback, show vulnerability, and grow on the job. Their book is "An Everyone Culture."

episodes.title: 522: Isabel Allende on Fiction and Feminism
episodes.summary: The bestselling author describes her creative process and explains why she was always determined to have a career.

episodes.title: 521: The Condensed May 2016 Issue
episodes.summary: Amy Bernstein, editor of HBR, offers executive summaries of the major features.

episodes.title: 520: Understanding Agile Management
episodes.summary: Darrell Rigby of Bain and Jeff Sutherland of Scrum explain the rise of lean, iterative management tactics, and how to implement them yourself.

episodes.title: 519: Smart Managers Don't Compare People to the "Average"
episodes.summary: Todd Rose, the Director of the Mind, Brain, & Education program at the Harvard Graduate School of Education and the author of "The End of Average: How to Succeed in a World That Values Sameness," explains why we should stop using averages to understand individuals.

episodes.title: 518: Life's Work: Dr. Ruth Westheimer
episodes.summary: Iconic relationship expert Dr. Ruth discusses what she's learned over a long career.

episodes.title: 517: How to Say No to More Work
episodes.summary: Karen Dillon, author of the "HBR Guide to Office Politics", explains how to gracefully decline excessive projects–and thankless tasks.

episodes.title: 516: The Condensed April 2016 Issue
episodes.summary: Amy Bernstein, editor of HBR, offers executive summaries of the major features.

episodes.title: 515: Are Leaders Getting Too Emotional?
episodes.summary: There's a lot of crying and shouting both in politics and at the office. Gautam Mukunda of Harvard Business School and Gianpiero Petriglieri of INSEAD help us try to make sense of it all.

episodes.title: 514: Your Coworkers Should Know Your Salary
episodes.summary: Pay transparency is actually a way better system than pay secrecy. David Burkus, professor at Oral Roberts University and author of "Under New Management," explains why.

episodes.title: 513: Talking About Race at Work
episodes.summary: Kira Hudson Banks, Ph.D., is an Assistant Professor in the department of psychology at Saint Louis University, and a principal at consulting firm the Mouse and the Elephant. We spoke with her about why managers shouldn't wait for a controversy to start talking about race.

episodes.title: 512: The Art of the Interview
episodes.summary: Job interviews can feel more like a stylized ritual than a normal conversation. Esquire writer and journalist Cal Fussman, who's interviewed scores of people from Mikhail Gorbachev to Jeff Bezos to Dr. Dre, gives us his advice, from how to build trust with a subject to getting an honest answer to a tough question.

episodes.title: 511: The Condensed March 2016 Issue
episodes.summary: Amy Bernstein, editor of HBR, offers executive summaries of the major features.

episodes.title: 510: Closing the Strategy-Execution Gap
episodes.summary: Paul Leinwand, co-author of the book "Strategy That Works," explains how successful companies solve this thorny problem.

episodes.title: 509: Be a Superboss
episodes.summary: Lorne Michaels, Bill Walsh, Alice Waters–all have had a disproportionate impact in their respective industries through their knack for collecting and inspiring great talent. We hear how they do it from Sydney Finkelstein, the Steven Roth Professor of Management in Dartmouth’s Tuck School of Business and the author of "Superbosses: How Exceptional Leaders Manage the Flow of Talent".

episodes.title: 508: How to Give Constructive Feedback
episodes.summary: Jack Zenger and Joseph Folkman have administered thousands of 360-degree assessments through their consulting firm, Zenger/Folkman. This has given them a wealth of information about who benefits from criticism, and how to deliver it.

episodes.title: 507: Being Happier at Work
episodes.summary: Emma Seppälä, Stanford researcher and author of "The Happiness Track," explains the proven benefits of a positive outlook; simple ways to increase your sense of well-being; and why it's not about being ecstatic or excited all the time.

episodes.title: 506: Stop Focusing on Your Strengths
episodes.summary: Tomas Chamorro-Premuzic, professor at University College London and Columbia University and CEO of Hogan Assessments, explains how the fad for strengths-based coaching may actually be weakening us.

episodes.title: 505: Make Peace with Your Inner Critic
episodes.summary: Tara Mohr, author of Playing Big, explains how to deal with self-doubt (or help someone else manage theirs).

episodes.title: 504: Achieve Your Goals (Finally)
episodes.summary: Heidi Grant Halvorson, author of "No One Understands You and What to Do About It" and "9 Things Successful People Do Differently," explains how to actually stick to your resolutions this year.'

episodes.title: 503: Marketing Lessons for Companies Big and Small
episodes.summary: Denise Lee Yohn, author of "Extraordinary Experiences" and "What Great Brands Do," explains what we can learn from retail and restaurant brands

episodes.title: 502: The Condensed January-February 2016 Issue
episodes.summary: Amy Bernstein, editor of HBR, offers executive summaries of the major features.

episodes.title: 501: Life's Work: Neil deGrasse Tyson
episodes.summary: In every issue, we feature a conversation with someone who's been wildly successful outside the traditional business world. This time, it's an astrophysicist.

episodes.title: 500: Becoming a More Authentic Leader
episodes.summary: Bill George, Harvard Business School professor and author of "Discover Your True North," gives advice to both new and experienced leaders.

episodes.title: 499: Accenture's CEO on Leading Change
episodes.summary: Pierre Nanterme discusses the forces changing consulting, and other knowledge-intensive industries.

episodes.title: 498: 4 Types of Conflict and How to Manage Them
episodes.summary: Amy Gallo, author of the "HBR Guide to Managing Conflict at Work," explains the options.

episodes.title: 497: The Condensed December 2015 Issue
episodes.summary: Amy Bernstein, editor of HBR, offers executive summaries of the major features.

episodes.title: 496: Katie Couric on the Shifting Landscape of News
episodes.summary: The renowned American journalist talks with HBR senior editor Dan McGinn.

episodes.title: 495: Slide Deck Presentations Don't Have to Be Terrible
episodes.summary: Evan Loomis and Evan Baehr, coauthors of "Get Backed," on how to win someone over with PowerPoint.

episodes.title: 494: Simple Rules for Creating Great Places to Work
episodes.summary: Gareth Jones, author of "Why Should Anyone Work Here?", explains the things managers know, but struggle to do.

episodes.title: 493: The Man Behind Siri Explains How to Start a Company
episodes.summary: Norman Winarsky, coauthor of "If You Really Want to Change the World," on ventures that scale.

episodes.title: 492: China and the Biggest Startup You've Probably Never Heard of
episodes.summary: Clay Shirky talks about Xiaomi, the subject of his new book, "Little Rice."

episodes.title: 491: What Makes Social Entrepreneurs Successful?
episodes.summary: Sally Osberg, president and CEO of the Skoll Foundation and author of "Getting Beyond Better" with Roger Martin.

episodes.title: 490: The Condensed November 2015 Issue
episodes.summary: Amy Bernstein, editor of HBR, offers executive summaries of the major features.

episodes.title: 489: Disrupt Your Career, and Yourself
episodes.summary: Whitney Johnson, author of "Disrupt Yourself," on taking the big risks we secretly want to.

episodes.title: 488: Why the Term "Thought Leader" Isn't Gross
episodes.summary: Dorie Clark, author of "Stand Out," on having more influence.

episodes.title: 487: Your Office's Hidden Artists and How to Work with Them
episodes.summary: Kimberly Elsbach, author of the HBR article "Collaborating with Creative Peers," on collaborating better with a certain type of colleague.

episodes.title: 486: Build Your Character (at Least for a Day)
episodes.summary: Tiffany Shlain, filmmaker, on why we need more time to develop our inner selves.

episodes.title: 485: The Creator of WordPress
episodes.summary: Matt Mullenweg, founder and CEO of Automattic, on growth, leadership, and mindfulness.

episodes.title: 484: The Condensed October 2015 Issue
episodes.summary: Amy Bernstein, editor of HBR, offers executive summaries of the major features.

episodes.title: 483: What's Your Digital Quotient?
episodes.summary: Kate Smaje of McKinsey explains how it's about more than being tech-savvy.

episodes.title: 482: PepsiCo CEO Indra Nooyi on Design Thinking
episodes.summary: How PepsiCo is harnessing the power of design.

episodes.title: 481: Salman Rushdie on Creativity and Criticism
episodes.summary: The acclaimed writer describes how he develops his novels, what he expects from reviewers, and why business people should still read fiction.

episodes.title: 480: Become a Better Listener
episodes.summary: Mark Goulston, psychiatrist and author of "Just Listen," explains how.

episodes.title: 479: The Condensed September 2015 Issue
episodes.summary: Amy Bernstein, editor of HBR, offers executive summaries of the major features.

episodes.title: 478: Building Healthy Teams
episodes.summary: Mary Shapiro, author of the "HBR Guide to Leading Teams" and professor at Simmons, on dealing with conflict and other issues.

episodes.title: 477: How Science and Tech Are Changing the Human Body
episodes.summary: Juan Enriquez and Steve Gullans explain how we're "evolving ourselves."

episodes.title: 476: The CEO of YP on Leading Digital Transformation
episodes.summary: David Krantz, the CEO of YP (formerly the Yellow Pages), explains how they've reinvented their business.

episodes.title: 475: "Social Media-Savvy CEO" Is No Oxymoron
episodes.summary: Charlene Li, author of "The Engaged Leader," on why and how senior executives are diving into online networks.

episodes.title: 474: Test-Taking Comes to the Office
episodes.summary: Tomas Chamorro-Premuzic, author of the HBR article "Ace the Assessment," explores the rising practice of using tests in hiring and promotion decisions.

episodes.title: 473: Can HR Be Saved?
episodes.summary: Peter Cappelli, author of the HBR article, "Why We Love to Hate HR...and What HR Can Do About It," on perhaps the least popular function in business.

episodes.title: 472: Michael Lynton on Surviving the Biggest Corporate Hack in History
episodes.summary: The CEO of Sony Pictures Entertainment discusses the crisis with editor-in-chief Adi Ignatius.

episodes.title: 471: The Condensed July-August 2015 Issue
episodes.summary: Amy Bernstein, editor of HBR, offers executive summaries of the major features.

episodes.title: 470: Beating Digital Overload with Digital Tools
episodes.summary: Alexandra Samuel, online engagement expert and author of "Work Smarter with Social Media," on the tools you should use--and the ones you could be ignoring.

episodes.title: 469: Are Robots Really Coming for Our Jobs?
episodes.summary: James Bessen, economist and former software executive, on what we can learn from 19th century mill workers about innovation, wages, and technology.

episodes.title: 468: George Mitchell on Effective Negotiation
episodes.summary: The former U.S. Senate majority leader and U.S. envoy to Northern Ireland and the Middle East describes his approach to resolving disputes and fostering bipartisan compromise.

episodes.title: 467: Evernote's CEO on the New Ways We Work
episodes.summary: Phil Libin discusses the impact of technology--from Microsoft Word to wearables--on our collaboration and productivity.

episodes.title: 466: Making Sense of Digital Disruption
episodes.summary: R. "Ray" Wang, author of "Disrupting Digital Business" on how business is transforming.

episodes.title: 465: The Condensed June 2015 Issue
episodes.summary: Amy Bernstein, editor of HBR, offers executive summaries of the major features.

episodes.title: 464: Consumer Privacy in the Digital Age
episodes.summary: Timothy Morey and Allison Schoop, both of frog, on designing customer data systems that promote transparency and trust.

episodes.title: 463: Why We Pretend to Be Workaholics
episodes.summary: Erin Reid of Boston University on why men (but not women) feign long working hours.

episodes.title: 462: Ethical CEOs Finish First
episodes.summary: Fred Kiel, author of "Return on Character," explains his research on why being good benefits the bottom line.

episodes.title: 461: Brian Grazer on the Power of Curiosity
episodes.summary: The Oscar-winning producer explains why a passion for learning--about other people and pursuits--has been the key to his success.

episodes.title: 460: Understand How People See You
episodes.summary: Heidi Grant Halvorson, author of "No One Understands You and What to Do About It," explains the science of perception.

episodes.title: 459: The Condensed May 2015 Issue
episodes.summary: Amy Bernstein, editor of HBR, offers executive summaries of the major features.

episodes.title: 458: Making Health Care More Consumer-Driven
episodes.summary: Regina Herzlinger, Harvard Business School professor, talks about how to dismantle the barriers to innovation in care delivery.

episodes.title: 457: Case Study: Reinvent This Retailer
episodes.summary: Hear this story based on real events at J.C. Penney. A discussion with contributor Jill Avery and editor Andy O'Connell follows.

episodes.title: 456: Your Brain's Ideal Schedule
episodes.summary: Ron Friedman, Ph.D., author of "The Best Place to Work," on how to structure your day to get the most done.

episodes.title: 455: Blue Ocean Strategy and Red Ocean Traps
episodes.summary: Renée Mauborgne of INSEAD explains how a landmark idea is evolving. She is coauthor, along with W. Chan Kim, of "Blue Ocean Strategy, Expanded Edition (2015)."

episodes.title: 454: The Condensed April 2015 Issue
episodes.summary: Amy Bernstein, editor of HBR, offers executive summaries of the major features.

episodes.title: 453: Set Habits You'll Actually Keep
episodes.summary: Gretchen Rubin, author of "Better than Before: Mastering the Habits of Our Everyday Lives," explains that you've got to know your habit-setting style.

episodes.title: 452: Goldie Hawn on Female Leadership
episodes.summary: The Hollywood icon explains why she moved from acting to producing and directing, then launched a foundation that teaches mindfulness to kids.

episodes.title: 451: Be Less Reactive and More Proactive
episodes.summary: Peter Bregman, author of "Four Seconds," on changing the way you lead.

episodes.title: 450: Marissa Mayer's Yahoo
episodes.summary: Nicholas Carlson, author of "Marissa Mayer and the Fight to Save Yahoo," on the CEO's management style.

episodes.title: 449: Why Leadership Feels Awkward
episodes.summary: Herminia Ibarra, author of "Act Like a Leader, Think Like a Leader" and professor at INSEAD, on moving forward, even when it's not comfortable.

episodes.title: 448: The Condensed March 2015 Issue
episodes.summary: Amy Bernstein, editor of HBR, offers executive summaries of the major features.

episodes.title: 447: GoDaddy's CEO on Leading Change
episodes.summary: Blake Irving talks about the company's renewed focus on small businesses and bringing on a new leadership team.

episodes.title: 446: Signs You're Secretly Annoying Your Colleagues
episodes.summary: Muriel Maignan Wilkins, coauthor of "Own the Room," on the flaws everyone's too polite to point out.

episodes.title: 445: Innovation Needs a System
episodes.summary: David Duncan, senior partner at Innosight and coauthor of "Build an Innovation Engine in 90 Days," explains how to organize corporate creativity.

episodes.title: 444: What Still Stifles Ambitious Women
episodes.summary: Pamela Stone, professor at Hunter College, on the surprising findings from a massive study of MBAs.

episodes.title: 443: How to Negotiate Better
episodes.summary: Jeff Weiss, author of the "HBR Guide to Negotiating" and partner at Vantage Partners, explains how to prepare to be persuasive.

episodes.title: 442: Skills We Can Learn from Games
episodes.summary: Andrew Innes, game designer, product manager, and author of "What Board Games Can Teach Business."

episodes.title: 441: The Condensed January-February 2015 Issue
episodes.summary: Amy Bernstein, editor of HBR, offers executive summaries of the major features.

episodes.title: 440: What Makes Teams Smart (or Dumb)
episodes.summary: Cass Sunstein, Harvard professor and author of "Wiser: Getting Beyond Groupthink to Make Groups Smarter."

episodes.title: 439: Communicate Better with Your Global Team
episodes.summary: Tsedal Neeley, Harvard Business School professor, explains how globally distributed teams can collaborate better together.

episodes.title: 438: Explaining Silicon Valley's Success
episodes.summary: AnnaLee Saxenian, author of the classic book "Regional Advantage," still thinks the area's future is bright.

episodes.title: 437: Learning What Wiser Workers Know
episodes.summary: Dorothy Leonard, author of "Critical Knowledge Transfer" ​and Harvard Business School professor, on retaining organizational expertise.

episodes.title: 436: Making Good Decisions
episodes.summary: Stanford's Ron Howard, one of the fathers of decision analysis, explains how it's done.

episodes.title: 435: The Condensed December 2014 Issue
episodes.summary: Amy Bernstein, editor of HBR, offers executive summaries of the major features.

episodes.title: 434: Boris Johnson on Influence and Ambition
episodes.summary: The mayor of London explains why Churchill is a role model and whether his aspirations include the Prime Minister's office.

episodes.title: 433: How to Change Someone's Behavior with Minimal Effort
episodes.summary: Steve J. Martin, coauthor of "The Small Big: Small Changes That Spark Big Influence," on the little things that persuade.

episodes.title: 432: Is the Corporate Campus Dying?
episodes.summary: Jennifer Magnolfi, Founder & Principal Investigator at Programmable Habitats LLC, on how digital work, and the Internet of Things will fundamentally change the how we use the buildings and neighborhoods we work in.
